steps.text: Construct a well-designed building for food processing.
Maintain the building preventively.
Maintain daily pest management programs.
Address pests from facility and surrounding areas.
Follow federal and state regulations.
Design building for pest prevention.
Maintain short grass and trimmed shrubs.
Install paved access and proper drainage.
Create an 18- to 24-inch gravel strip around foundation.
Place night-lights at least 30 feet away from doors.
Keep framing at least four inches from walls.
Fill necessary voids with materials like polyurethane foam.
Install concrete or coated concrete floors.
Use acid-proof or brick floors for wet processing areas.
Seal and clean wall materials.
Prevent hollow panel-type walls from becoming insect quarters.
Install smooth and water-free roofs.
Use as few windows as possible with good transparency.
Install metal and tight-fitting doors.
Install air curtains at large doors.
Use good lighting with dust-tight fixtures.
Install electrical and plumbing services for easy access and cleaning.
Make control panels insect-proof.
Eliminate litter, waste, and uncut grass.
Pave dusty roads and maintain lawns.
Ensure proper drainage.
Position lighting away from buildings.
Reduce bird harborage and outside food spillage.
Use rodent, insect, and bird traps.
Maintain housekeeping and implement pest monitoring programs.
Maintain bait stations for rodent management.
Use insecticidal baits and approved insecticides near breeding sites.
Use chemical repellents and avicides where appropriate for bird management.
Rodent-proof all openings in buildings.
Screen windows.
Block bird access to ledges.
Locate equipment off the floor or sealed to it.
Inspect all incoming vehicles and materials.
Store materials away from walls for inspection access.
Use rodent traps near doors.
Use air curtains at doors.
Use deterrents for birds on roosting sites.
Implement a detailed monitoring program and a total facility IPM program in the processing area.
Use rodent traps near doors if needed.
Ensure proper sanitation in the processing area.
Use space treatments with nonresiduals, crack and crevice treatments with residuals, spot treatments, and fumigation for raw commodities in the warehouse.
Form an inspection committee and assign roles.
Conduct a thorough inspection of the plant.
Record all defects and distribute notes to department heads.
Departments correct identified defects.
Committee reviews notes, addresses uncorrected items, and assigns correction dates.
Sanitation is the responsibility of everyone in the plant.
Inspect areas using a flashlight to detect insect trails or mouse footprints.
Observe suspect stock by spreading it on a flat surface and watching for movement.
Inspect areas most likely to produce results, such as under and inside equipment.
Suspect any unaccounted-for voids in equipment or structures.
Observe employee actions and in-plant practices.
Reward good sanitation to encourage plant-wide cooperation.
Consider periodic inspections by an outside firm for a fresh perspective.
Check warehouse regulations, requiring an 18-inch space between pallets and walls.
Implement a written inspection procedure for incoming raw products.
Identify high mortality risk and its impact on stored product pests.
Implement good sanitation and temperature control to slow pest growth.
Minimize insect movement by inspecting incoming materials and designing buildings.
Use visual inspection as a key monitoring method.
Consider using lights to attract insects.
Place pheromone-baited traps for inspecting bagged commodities, identifying pests, determining the extent of a problem, and evaluating treatment methods.
Examine trends in trap catches over time to modify management practices and reduce populations.
Identify common insect pests in raw grain and processed food.
Select appropriate trap types based on the environment.
Place traps on the outer perimeter of a facility for interception and prediction.
Monitor trap catches for increases in numbers from one period to the next.
Implement a pest management plan, including monitoring and inspection, building modifications, non-chemical control, and chemical control.
Read the label carefully.
Ensure application in food-handling establishments adheres to labels.
Understand different types of residual applications (general, spot, crack and crevice).
Follow pesticide regulations at the federal and state levels.
Identify life cycle stages of beetles and moths: egg, larva, pupa, and adult.
Understand beetle and moth larva characteristics: chewing mouthparts, feed on food.
Determine differences between beetle and moth larvae: moth larvae have legs, beetle larvae do not.
Recognize adult beetles: chewing mouthparts, feed on various materials.
Inspect food products for moths and beetles.

Identify specific pests: Almond Moth, Indianmeal Moth, Mediterranean Flour Moth, Mealmoth, Lesser Grain Borer, Cigarette Beetle, Drugstore Beetle, Confused Flour Beetle, Sawtoothed Grain Beetle, Merchant Grain Beetle, or Foreign Grain Beetle.
Implement control measures based on pest identification: Avoidance, Sanitation, Heat Treatment, Cold Treatment, Residual Insecticides, Space Sprays, or Fumigation.
Monitor food products for reinfestation.
Identify pests: Spider Beetles, Warehouse Beetle / Dermestid Beetles, Cockroaches, Flies, Ants, Bees and Wasps, Booklice.
Determine pest characteristics: appearance, behavior, preferred environments, signs of infestation.
Identify control methods based on pest type: sanitation, residual pesticides, dusts, contact sprays, nest treatment.
Identify pest species: Silverfish, Firebrats, Crickets, Ground Beetles, Sowbugs and Pillbugs or Rodents.
Understand pest behavior: senses, reactions, agility.
Recognize signs of infestation: droppings, runways, rubmarks, burrows, tracks, urine.
Implement rodent management strategies: sanitation and habitat modification, rodent-proof construction.
Clean hose, valve, and nozzle after each use.
Check gaskets and valves regularly.
Never leave pressurized equipment unattended.
Choose appropriate nozzle for spray pattern.
Maintain dusters by keeping them clean and dry.
Follow instructions for using space treating equipment.
Wear appropriate respiratory protection as needed.
Perform daily negative and positive pressure checks.
Wash respirators regularly.
Store respirators in a clean, protected place.

constraints.text: Use IPM (Integrated Pest Management) for managing pests in food processing facilities.
Thorough inspections must be conducted in obscure places.
Requirements for warehouse and raw product receiving inspections by law.
Use pheromone-baited traps for inspecting bagged commodities, identifying pests, determining the extent of a problem, and evaluating treatment methods.
One trap per 4,000-5,000 square feet in high-risk areas.
Match trap types to the environment (dusty vs. clean, hot vs. cold).
Place traps on the outer perimeter of a facility for interception and prediction.
Ensure pesticides used on food products have tolerances or are exempt.
Do not apply pesticides in a manner inconsistent with their labeling (FIFRA law).
Understand the importance of identifying life cycle stages for effective pest control.
Moths and beetles can contaminate food products.
Proper identification of pests is crucial for effective control measures.
Ensure proper identification of pests before implementing control methods.
Follow safety guidelines when handling pesticides and protective clothing for bees and wasps.
Ensure proper identification of pests before implementing control measures.
Ensure safety and effectiveness of equipment by following maintenance procedures.
Use appropriate nozzle for desired spray pattern.
Perform daily checks to ensure proper fit and function.
Avoid wearing beards while using respirators for a tight seal.

Training Manual
Classification 7
University of Arkansas System, Division of Agriculture, Research & Extension
